question: [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: RawDataServer unmatched path handler] [Information disclosure] Does the default handler at lines 267-280 leak information about internal service structure by returning status 200 with Unimplemented instead of 404, potentially helping attackers map available endpoints? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: RawDataServer unmatched path handler] [Response body handling] Can the empty_body() call at line 277 cause issues if the underlying HTTP implementation expects a properly closed body stream, leading to connection leaks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: RawDataServer::clone()] [Clone safety] When cloning RawDataServer at line 285-295, are compression encodings and message size limits properly copied, or can modifications to the clone affect the original server instance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Trait: RawData] [Trait implementation validation] Can malicious implementations of the RawData trait at line 126 return arbitrary GetTransactionsStream types that don't properly validate transaction data, serving corrupted or fabricated transactions to indexers? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Type: GetTransactionsStream] [Stream type safety] Does the GetTransactionsStream type bound (lines 128-132) enforce proper error handling, or can implementation errors in the stream cause panics that crash the indexer service? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerClient::connect()] [Endpoint validation] Can an attacker supply a malicious endpoint to the GrpcManager client that performs SSRF attacks by connecting to internal services or metadata endpoints? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerClient::heartbeat()] [Heartbeat spoofing] Can an attacker send forged heartbeat requests with manipulated HeartbeatRequest data to trick the manager into thinking a failing indexer node is healthy, causing traffic routing to unavailable services? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerClient::heartbeat() ready check] [Service availability bypass] Does the ready() check at lines 395-403 properly validate service health, or can an attacker send heartbeat requests during degraded states that cause cascading failures? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerClient::heartbeat() error mapping] [Error information leakage] Does the error message format at line 401 leak sensitive information about internal service state or configuration when mapping transport errors to tonic::Status? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerClient::get_transactions()] [Unary transaction request] Can an attacker exploit the unary get_transactions endpoint to bypass rate limiting that might be applied to streaming requests, allowing bulk transaction data exfiltration? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerClient::get_transactions() path routing] [Path manipulation] Can the hardcoded path '/aptos.indexer.v1.GrpcManager/GetTransactions' at line 431-433 be exploited if the server has inconsistent path parsing, routing to unintended handlers? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerClient::get_data_service_for_request()] [Service discovery abuse] Can an attacker manipulate GetDataServiceForRequestRequest parameters to receive routing information to internal or unauthorized data services, bypassing access controls? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerClient::get_data_service_for_request() error handling] [Timing attack] Do the error handling paths at lines 449-457 have timing differences that could leak information about valid vs invalid service discovery requests? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerClient::with_interceptor()] [Interceptor chain vulnerability] Can an attacker bypass authentication by exploiting the interceptor chain construction at lines 337-354, potentially skipping credential validation? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerClient compression methods] [Compression negotiation] Can an attacker manipulate compression settings to force inefficient encoding/decoding that causes CPU exhaustion on the manager service? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Trait: GrpcManager] [Trait bound enforcement] Does the GrpcManager trait at line 480 properly enforce Send + Sync + 'static bounds, or can malicious implementations introduce thread-safety issues with shared state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerServer::new()] [Default configuration vulnerability] Are the default settings for accept_compression_encodings and send_compression_encodings secure, or do they enable dangerous compression schemes by default? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerServer::poll_ready()] [Always-ready pattern] Does returning Poll::Ready(Ok(())) at line 579 without checking actual resource availability allow request acceptance when the service should reject connections due to resource exhaustion? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerServer::call() heartbeat handler] [Heartbeat injection] Can an attacker send malicious heartbeat requests that manipulate service health metrics or routing decisions by exploiting the HeartbeatSvc handler at lines 583-626? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: HeartbeatSvc::call()] [Async heartbeat handling] Does the async move block at lines 600-602 properly handle cancellations, or can interrupted heartbeats leave the service in an inconsistent health state? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.tonic.rs] [Function: GrpcManagerServer get_transactions handler] [Transaction request validation] Does the GetTransactionsSvc handler at lines 628-671 validate request parameters before processing, or can attackers request arbitrary transaction ranges?
